organic_results.title: Technical change and the expansion of schooling in the United States, 1890-1970
organic_results.snippet: This article focuses on the historical expansion of school enrollments in the United States by analyzing one of the most debated factors in theories of schooling: the role of technological change. Although some previous works have attacked the idea that schooling expands in response to technical change, we find that technical change has been an important, though not dominant, factor in expanding primary-and secondary-school enrollments. Our findings are derived from studying the effects of technical change within a model of school expansion …

publication_info.summary: R Rubinson, J Ralph - Sociology of Education, 1984 - JSTOR

organic_results.title: Immigration and the Expansion of Schooling in the United States, 1890-1970
organic_results.snippet: Our research analyzes the effects of immigration on the rate of growth of educational expansion in the United States from 1890 to 1970. Previous studies have shown that the presence of nativist, Protestant-millenial groups was associated with the early expansion of public primary enrollments. Immigrant groups provide an important contrast to such groups, and several interpretive histories of United States education stress the relationship between immigration and schooling. Using aggregate, time-series analyses, we find that:(1) …
